content: The message comes from thundebird because it is relaying the message from your email provider. That may be due to a misconfiguration of the setup, or the provider may have different requirements for passwords when used from a PC (Gmail is an example of that.) If you post more information, such as domain name and/or input and output settings used (screenshots are preferred, someone here may have suggestions. Please also include full text of error message. Thank you
creator: davidsk

content:
Purtroppo se le versioni sono molti diverse, problemi di questo genere possono capitare.

Prova ad inserire manualmente la password: Menu > Impostazioni > Privacy e sicurezza > Password > [Password salvate] Click su [Mostra password] Click destro sull'account -> Modifica password
creator: @next

content: Purtroppo nella sezione password salvate non ho nessuna informazione la schermata risulta completamente vuota sembra che la funzione di salvataggio della password sia inibita o disattivata
creator: s.riva

content:
Two comments: if you were asked to reenter your account, that may be that thunderbird created a new profile. If so, you can click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - the next screen will show whatever profiles are there. you can click an 'open' button to browse one. -in a profile, IMAP accounts would be in the imapmail folder, POP in the mail folder and local folders in the mail\Local Folders folders - if you see your accounts in one of the unused profiles, you have found your data and can launch that profile.

if you're restoring from a prior profile, you will want to replace the one at ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\, not appdata\local - do that when thunderbird is NOT running.
creator: davidsk

content:
Did you follow these steps? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

Did you have to enter your account information when starting thunderbird? Sharing more info may help.
creator: davidsk

content:
I was very careful to follow the instructions carefully and I closed TB on both machines. Some files could not be copied on the source machine. On the target, it would not allow me to "remove" the folders, so I tried to overwrite them. That also did not work. Now the target version of TB does not work at all. Fortunately, I cloned the SSD of that machine and am restoring it now. I am giving up on this for now.

My current problem is that TB does not start up automatically when I turn the source PC on any more. Not sure why. I added a shortcut to the Start folder. Thoughts please.
